title: Corned Beef Hash Arepas
description: Arepas (maize cakes) are split and filled with browned corned beef hash, black beans, tomato, avocado, and a poached egg.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Breakfast and Brunch Corned Beef Hash Arepas 5.0 (3) 3 Reviews 6 Photos Arepas are served with corned beef hash, black beans, fresh avocado, tomato, and topped with a poached egg. A South of the Border version of a breakfast muffin sandwich. Submitted by Buckwheat Queen Updated on March 13, 2025 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 6 6 6 6 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 12 mins Total Time: 27 mins Servings: 4 Yield: 4 servings Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings 1 (15 ounce) can Corned Beef Hash or leftover corned beef ½ yellow onion, chopped 1 tablespoon vegetable oil 1 cup cooked black beans, rinsed and drained 4 eggs 4 arepas (cooked corn flour cakes, see Cook's Note) 1 tomato, sliced 1 avocado - peeled, pitted and sliced Directions In a skillet over medium-high heat, saute the onion in the oil until soft and translucent, about 4 minutes. Add the can of corned beef hash and black beans. Cook until the mixture is heated throughout and slightly crispy, 4 to 6 minutes. Remove from heat. Fill a large saucepan with 2 to 3 inches of water and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low, pour in vinegar, and keep the water at a gentle simmer. Crack an egg into a small bowl then gently slip egg into the simmering water, holding the bowl just above the surface of water. Repeat with the remaining eggs. Cook eggs until the whites are firm and the yolks have thickened but are not hard, 2 1/2 to 3 minutes. Remove the eggs from the water with a slotted spoon, dab on a kitchen towel to remove excess water, and place onto a warm plate. Cut the arepas in half horizontally. Distribute corned beef hash mixture on the bottom halves of the arepas. Top with slices of tomato and avocado and a poached egg. Close with arepa tops and serve. Cook’s Note You can also use home-made Arepas. Add Your Photo Photos of Corned Beef Hash Arepas 01 of 06 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 06 Photo by  lauramarch78 07/06/2021 My husband loved it!! I didn't make it to exact directions. Instead of arepas I used corn bread and omitted the black beans. I would definitely make again. 03 of 06 Photo by  Soup Loving Nicole 07/19/2017 What a great way to utilize corned beef hash. I did add some hot picante sauce to the mixture for some heat but that is the only change I made. I overcooked my egg (user error) but it still turned out good. Great recipe and a unique spin on your every day typical hash. Think South of the border breakfast...brunch...lunch..or even dinner. It works for all of them. Thanks for the great recipe Buckwheat Queen! 04 of 06 Photo by  Soup Loving Nicole 07/19/2017 What a great way to utilize corned beef hash. I did add some hot picante sauce to the mixture for some heat but that is the only change I made. I overcooked my egg (user error) but it still turned out good. Great recipe and a unique spin on your every day typical hash. Think South of the border breakfast...brunch...lunch..or even dinner. It works for all of them. name: Buckwheat Queen

Reduce the heat to medium-low, pour in vinegar, and keep the water at a gentle simmer. Crack an egg into a small bowl then gently slip egg into the simmering water, holding the bowl just above the surface of water. Repeat with the remaining eggs. Cook eggs until the whites are firm and the yolks have thickened but are not hard, 2 1/2 to 3 minutes. Distribute corned beef hash mixture on the bottom halves of the arepas. Top with slices of tomato and avocado and a poached egg. Close with arepa tops and serve.
